item.title: My SPY Put Credit Spread Trades For April 2019
item.description: April showers bring epic put credit spread trades! Another good month of trading! Our Put Credit Spreads strategy is looking good! We are officially back to even from our January drawdown. This has been a good lesson in how drawdowns work. item.title: My SPY Put Credit Spread Trades For March 2019
item.description: March had some good trades!! A very winning month. The best part about the month, for me at least, is Oregon had some epic snow. I had some amazing turns in! I digress.....back to options. Our Put Credit Spreads strategy is looking good! If April is a good month we should be back to even from our January drawdown. item.description: February......The month of love.....(at least here in the US)......The market gave us tons of love!! Finally, some winning trades this month for our Put Credit Spreads strategy. These wins really helped build back up our drawdown from past months. item.title: My SPY Put Credit Spread Trades For January 2019
item.description: More losses this month for our Put Credit Spreads strategy. Mainly a losing trade that was put on in 2018 and crossed over. I think the markets are calming down and we will start to draw back up. We did have one winning trade which felt good. Take the little wins :). item.title: My SPY Put Credit Spread Trades For December 2018
item.description: Wow! What an unfortunate month for Put Credit Spreads. Afraid this month returned all my yearly gains and then some. A bit of a disappointing way to end the year. We know months like this will happen. Big drawdowns are part of the overall strategy. The key is to take advantage when times are good to build up a stockpile of reserves. TickerTypeSpreadExpire DateOpen DateClosed DateOpen CreditClosed DebitProfit / LossSPY Put 250/252 12/14/2018 11/23/18 12/03/18 $0.

item.title: My SPY Put Credit Spread Trades For November 2018
item.description: Well, finally an engaging month for Put Credit Spreads. Afraid the engagement was in the wrong direction. In November we took some losses. Not a big deal since we have had so many winning past months. However, losses are never fun. item.title: My SPY Put Credit Spread Trades For October 2018
item.description: With October 2018 completed we move on to November. Again this was a little bit of a boring month as we only closed one trade. We do have some trades on the board that will close in November. My fingers are crossed for more excitement. TickerTypeSpreadExpire DateOpen DateClosed DateOpen CreditClosed DebitProfit / LossSPY Put 274/276 10/19/2018 09/05/18 10/03/18 $0.2 $0.03 9.44% This is how put credit spreads go. item.description: With September 2018 over we look forward to autumn. This was a little bit of a boring month as we only closed one trade. We do have some trades on the board that will close in October. item.title: My SPY Put Credit Spread Trades For August 2018
item.description: With August 2018 in the bag we look forward to September. Traders leave their Hamptons pads and get back to work. My SPY Put Credit Spread trading strategy only closed one trade this month. Hoping for a creep up in IVR next month. TickerTypeSpreadExpire DateOpen DateClosed DateOpen CreditClosed DebitProfit / LossSPY Put 268/270 09/21/2018 08/13/18 08/29/18 $0.2 $0.03 9.44% Months like this make us wonder if trading put credit spreads is even worth it but I can assure you it is par for the course.

item.title: My SPY Put Credit Spread Trades For July 2018
item.description: July has come and gone. We partied for America's birthday and closed a few profitable trades! Darn good month! July 2018 was another winning month for my SPY Put Credit Spread trading strategy. However, only closing 3 trades for the month is a bit of a sign. Makes me think the market is stalling and might change direction. Low volatility is never a comfortable place to be in. I am starting to prepare for a pull back.

item.title: My SPY Put Credit Spread Trades For June 2018
item.description: June 2018 was another winning month for my SPY Put Credit Spread trading strategy. Since IVR has been pretty low closing this many trades was a darn good thing. Just have to be careful to not trade too big. Overall this was a low number of trades for a month -- hence one might want to start increasing trade size. I would not suggest that. A down draw is always just round the corner.

item.title: My SPY Put Credit Spread Trades For May 2018
item.description: As you can see from my trades in the table below May 2018 was a winning month. This is a great example of good times with this strategy. With my Put Credit Spread Trades strategy we have good months, bad months, and "meh" months. It was a nice surprise to have this good month after a losing month. Helps get back our losses. TickerTypeSpreadExpire DateOpen DateClosed DateOpen CreditClosed DebitProfit / LossSPY Put 249/251 05/18/2018 04/10/18 05/09/18 $0.

item.title: My SPY Put Credit Spread Trades For April 2018
item.description: As you can see from my trades in the table below April 2018 was a losing month. This is a great example of when things go bad -- and they always do. Honestly, this was not even a bad month compared to other bad months. Based on an average net credit of $0.23 it will take 5 winning SPY Put Credit Spread Trades to get back the losses from this month.

item.title: My SPY Put Credit Spread Trades For March 2018
item.description: Here we explore the put credit spread trades I placed on the SPY durning the month of March 2018. This is my primary trading strategy for monthly income. By trading put credit spreads on the SPY I am typically in a trade for 23 days but no more than 45 days. item.title: My SPY Put Credit Spread Trades For February 2018
item.description: And the fun has started again. I thought this day would never come. Our markets have been so boring for so long -- volatility is back! Sadly I took some losses this month. Losses goes with the strategy it happens from time to time, particularly when the market tanks. The good news is once the decline starts you can pick up some good trades at high opening credits to offset the losses.

item.title: My SPY Put Credit Spread Trades For January 2018 (or lack there of)
item.description: Thanks to the Trump tax cuts the market in January 2018 was pretty stable. Just creeping up in value each day. With volatility so low there were not many opportunities for SPY Put Credit Spread Trades. While I opened a few trades none closed. At the end of January the tax party came to an end and the market got cray cray. Lots to report in my February 2018 update.

item.title: Baseline Strategy for Trading SPY Put Credit Spreads
item.description: When I got interested in trading credit spreads, like most I harbored some skepticism. A credit spread trade seemed to be the type that works—until rather dramatically it does not. More than once I put on a series of successful trades and then Dr. Jeckyll transformed into his evil alter ego Mr. Hyde and suddenly I was blowing up my account. Clearly, I did not know what I was doing. On the verge of giving up, I convinced myself that I was just missing something.

item.title: Should I Consider Delta When Opening SPY Put Credit Spreads?
item.description: Delta is a metric that options traders use to predict how the price of an option will change when the underlying stock moves by one dollar. If, for example, a call option has a delta of .3 and the underlying stock value increases from $100 to $101, then theoretically that call option would increase in value by $0.30. Delta is also a probability proxy. You can think of delta as the probability the option will expire in the money—so in other words that call option with a delta of .

item.title: Being Hyperfocused on the SPY
item.description: Almost all of my credit spread trading is focused on the S&P 500 via the SPY or S&P 500 futures. Why am I hyperfocused on the SPY? So I can sleep at night (well, try to sleep—I do have a young son and a daughter on the way). The S&P 500 is such a big index that it generally doesn’t move dramatically. In contrast, Netflix recently posted a 31% change in a single week, which is just too much for me to handle.

item.title: How Often the SPY Falls More Than 5% in a 30-Day Period and Why You Should Care
item.description: During any 30-day period from 1993 through 2014 the SPY (the Exchange Traded Funds, or ETFs, tracking the S&P 500) closed down 5% or more 11% of the time. I know this obscure fact because for every one of the 5,502 trading days during that period I compared the SPY closing price with the closing price 30 trading days later. (My results can be found here.) And that’s not all: Further examination of 30-day periods that closed down more than 5% within shorter time frames (say 3 years) revealed rates as high as 20% during extreme bear markets (hello real estate meltdown) and as low as 3% during bull markets.
